channel.title: Security and civil rights
channel.description:
Interviews on balancing national security interests with personal liberty. The series is moderated by Monrad Paulsen of Columbia University.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: James R. Wilson, Jr. and Patrick Murphy Malin
item.description: James R. Wilson, Jr., American Legion; and Patrick Murphy Malin, American Civil Liberties Union, discuss national security.
item.dc:creator: KUOM (Radio station : Minneapolis, Minn.)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Howard Smith
item.description: Congressman Howard Smith, author of The Smith Act; John B. Olversson, United States Chamber of Commerce; Joseph L. Rauh, Jr., Americans for Democratic Action; Royal W. France, National Lawyer's Guild, all debate special laws related to national security.
item.dc:creator: KUOM (Radio station : Minneapolis, Minn.)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and Congressman John Moss
item.description: Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and Congressman John Moss discuss government committees evaluating security and secrecy.
item.dc:creator: KUOM (Radio station : Minneapolis, Minn.)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Dr. Marie Jahoda
item.description: Dr. Marie Jahoda, New York University, reports on a study she directed on the personal and psychological aspects of security loyalty programs.
item.dc:creator: KUOM (Radio station : Minneapolis, Minn.)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Series summary
item.description: A summary of this series, presented by Dudley B. Bonsal, New York State Bar Association; and Professor Monrad Paulsen of Columbia University.
item.dc:creator: KUOM (Radio station : Minneapolis, Minn.)
item.dc:subject: World Politics

item.title: Alan Barth
item.description: Journalist Alan Barth, author of "The Loyalty of Free Men" and "Government by Investigation" discusses some effects of the security loyalty programs on the fundamentals of freedom and democracy.
item.dc:creator: KUOM (Radio station : Minneapolis, Minn.)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Howard Smith
item.description: Congressman Howard Smith, author of The Smith Act; John B. Olversson, United States Chamber of Commerce; Joseph L. Rauh, Jr., Americans for Democratic Action; Royal W. France, National Lawyer's Guild, all debate special laws related to national security.
item.dc:creator: KUOM (Radio station : Minneapolis, Minn.)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Adam Yarmolinsky
item.description: Adam Yarmolinsky, secretary of the Fund for the Republic, reports on specific security cases and how they affect those involved. He directed the collection of case studies in personnel security.
item.dc:creator: KUOM (Radio station : Minneapolis, Minn.)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Joseph A. Fanelli, Jr., Leo Lightner, Paul Porter, William Rogers, and Leonard Boudine
item.description: Attorneys Joseph A. Fanelli, Jr.; Leo Lightner; Paul Porter; William Rogers; and Leonard Boudine discuss security cases involving Owen Lattimore and Dr. John P. Peters.
item.dc:creator: KUOM (Radio station : Minneapolis, Minn.)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Telford Taylor
item.description: Telford Taylor, former counsel for the Federal Communications Commission, General in Military Intelligence, U.S. Chief Prosecutor for the War Crimes Trial in Nuremburg, discusses self-incrimination.
item.dc:creator: KUOM (Radio station : Minneapolis, Minn.)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: C. Dickerman Williams, Dr. Harry Slochower and Ephraim London
item.description: C. Dickerman Williams, Dr. Harry Slochower and Ephraim London debate the merits of the Fifth Amendment. Slochower and London were recorded a few days after a relevant U.S. Supreme Court ruling.
item.dc:creator: KUOM (Radio station : Minneapolis, Minn.)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Owen Lattimore
item.description: Owen Lattimore, Johns Hopkins University faculty member, authority on the Far East, and central figure of a celebrated security case, is interviewed at his Baltimore home on being charged with security breach.
item.dc:creator: KUOM (Radio station : Minneapolis, Minn.)
item.dc:subject: War & Civil Defense

item.title: Dudley B. Bonsal
item.description: The first program in the series features Dudley B. Bonsal, chair of the New York State Bar Association committee, evaluating government security and loyalty programs.
item.dc:creator: KUOM (Radio station : Minneapolis, Minn.)
item.dc:subject: World Politics
